canonical_explanation.text: Reproduction is the biological process by which organisms produce new individuals of their own kind. Plants reproduce through two main modes: asexual reproduction (involving a single parent, no fusion of gametes) and sexual reproduction (involving two parents, fusion of male and female gametes). Asexual reproduction methods include vegetative propagation (new plants grow from parts like stems, roots, or leaves), budding (a small outgrowth develops into a new organism, as in yeast), fragmentation (organism breaks into fragments, each growing into a new individual, as in Spirogyra), and spore formation (spores are released that grow into new plants, as in ferns and mushrooms). In sexual reproduction, flowers are the reproductive organs. A typical flower has four parts: sepals, petals, stamens (male part with anther and filament), and pistil (female part with stigma, style, and ovary). Pollination is the transfer of pollen from anther to stigma - self-pollination (same flower or same plant) and cross-pollination (different plant, by wind, water, insects, or animals). After pollination, fertilisation occurs when the male gamete fuses with the female gamete in the ovule. The ovule develops into a seed and the ovary into a fruit. Seeds are dispersed by wind, water, animals, and explosive mechanisms.
rules: Asexual reproduction involves one parent; sexual reproduction involves two gametes.
Vegetative propagation: new plants from stems (rose, sugarcane), leaves (bryophyllum), roots (dahlia).
Budding: outgrowth develops into new organism (yeast, hydra).
Fragmentation: organism breaks into pieces, each growing into a new individual (Spirogyra).
Spore formation: microscopic spores germinate into new organisms (ferns, mushrooms).
Flower parts: sepals (protect bud), petals (attract pollinators), stamens (male), pistil (female).
Stamen = anther + filament; Pistil = stigma + style + ovary.
Self-pollination: pollen transferred within the same flower or plant; Cross-pollination: between different plants.
Fertilisation: fusion of male and female gametes inside the ovule.
After fertilisation: ovule becomes seed, ovary becomes fruit. Seeds are dispersed by wind, water, animals, explosion.

questions.question_text: Reproduction in which only one parent is involved is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Asexual reproduction involves only one parent and does not involve the fusion of male and female gametes. The offspring are genetically identical to the parent. Examples include budding, fragmentation, and vegetative propagation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sexual reproduction (A) involves two gametes. Pollination (C) is the transfer of pollen. Fertilisation (D) is the fusion of gametes. Only asexual reproduction (B) involves a single parent.

questions.question_text: Sexual reproduction in plants involves the fusion of:
questions.explanation_correct: Sexual reproduction involves the fusion (joining) of male and female gametes (sex cells). In flowering plants, the male gamete is in the pollen grain and the female gamete is in the ovule of the pistil.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Spores (A) are involved in asexual reproduction. Seeds and fruits (C) are products of sexual reproduction. Leaves and roots (D) can be involved in vegetative propagation. Gamete fusion (B) defines sexual reproduction.

questions.question_text: New plants growing from the leaves of Bryophyllum is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Bryophyllum reproduces through vegetative propagation from its leaves. Small plantlets (buds) grow along the margins of the leaf, which fall to the ground and develop into new independent plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Budding (A) is seen in yeast. Fragmentation (B) occurs in organisms like Spirogyra. Spore formation (D) occurs in ferns. Bryophyllum reproduces by vegetative propagation (C) from leaves.

questions.question_text: Yeast reproduces by:
questions.explanation_correct: Yeast reproduces asexually by budding. A small bud-like outgrowth appears on the parent yeast cell, gradually grows, and eventually separates to form a new yeast cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fragmentation (A) occurs in Spirogyra. Spore formation (B) occurs in mushrooms and ferns. Seed formation (D) is sexual reproduction. Yeast reproduces by budding (C).

questions.question_text: Spirogyra reproduces by breaking into fragments, each of which grows into a new individual. This is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Fragmentation is the mode of asexual reproduction where the body of an organism breaks into two or more fragments, and each fragment grows into a complete new organism. Spirogyra is a classic example.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Budding (A) involves growth of a bud. Vegetative propagation (C) uses plant parts like stems and leaves. Pollination (D) is part of sexual reproduction. Fragmentation (B) is the breaking of the body into parts.

questions.question_text: Mushrooms reproduce by:
questions.explanation_correct: Mushrooms reproduce asexually by spore formation. They produce millions of tiny spores under their cap. These spores are carried by wind or water to new places where they germinate into new mushrooms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mushrooms do not produce seeds (A) or reproduce by budding (B) or fragmentation (D). They reproduce by producing and releasing spores (C).

questions.question_text: The male reproductive part of a flower is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The stamen is the male reproductive part of a flower. It consists of two parts: the anther (which produces pollen grains containing male gametes) and the filament (which supports the anther).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pistil (A) is the female part. Petals (B) attract pollinators. Sepals (D) protect the flower bud. The stamen (C) is the male reproductive organ.

questions.question_text: The female reproductive part of a flower is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The pistil (or carpel) is the female reproductive part of a flower. It consists of three parts: the stigma (sticky top that receives pollen), the style (tube connecting stigma to ovary), and the ovary (contains ovules).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The stamen (A) is the male part. Petals (C) attract pollinators. Sepals (D) protect the bud. The pistil (B) is the female reproductive organ of a flower.

questions.question_text: Pollen grains are produced in the:
questions.explanation_correct: Pollen grains are produced in the anther, which is the top part of the stamen (male reproductive organ). Each pollen grain contains the male gamete needed for fertilisation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The stigma (A) receives pollen. The ovary (B) contains ovules. The style (D) connects stigma to ovary. Pollen is produced in the anther (C) of the stamen.

questions.question_text: A flower that has both stamens and pistil is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A bisexual flower (also called a complete or perfect flower) contains both the male part (stamen) and the female part (pistil). Examples include mustard, rose, and hibiscus flowers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Unisexual (A) flowers have either stamens or pistil, not both. Incomplete (C) means missing one of the four whorls. Sterile (D) means cannot reproduce. Bisexual (B) means both male and female parts are present.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a unisexual flower?
questions.explanation_correct: Papaya is an example of a unisexual flower, meaning it has either stamens (male flower) or pistil (female flower), but not both in the same flower. Watermelon and cucumber are other examples.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mustard (A), hibiscus (B), and rose (D) are bisexual flowers with both male and female parts. Papaya (C) has separate male and female flowers (unisexual).

questions.question_text: Pollination is the process of:

options.text: Fusion of male and female gametes
Transfer of pollen from anther to stigma

questions.explanation_correct: Pollination is the transfer of pollen grains from the anther (male part) to the stigma (female part) of a flower. It is a necessary step before fertilisation can occur.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fusion of gametes (A) is fertilisation. Seed dispersal (C) occurs after fruit formation. Fruit development (D) occurs after fertilisation. Pollination (B) is the transfer of pollen.

questions.question_text: When pollen is transferred from the anther to the stigma of the same flower, it is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Self-pollination occurs when pollen is transferred from the anther to the stigma of the same flower, or to another flower on the same plant. It does not require external agents.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cross-pollination (A) involves pollen transfer between different plants. Fertilisation (C) is gamete fusion. Germination (D) is the sprouting of a seed. Self-pollination (B) is within the same flower or plant.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT an agent of pollination?
questions.explanation_correct: Xylem is a plant tissue for transporting water and minerals, not an agent of pollination. The main agents of pollination are wind, water, insects, birds, and other animals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wind (A), insects (B), and water (D) are all natural agents that help transfer pollen between flowers. Xylem (C) is a transport tissue in plants and not involved in pollination.

questions.question_text: Fertilisation in plants is the process of:

options.text: Transfer of pollen to the stigma
Fusion of the male gamete with the female gamete

questions.explanation_correct: Fertilisation is the process where the male gamete (from the pollen grain) fuses with the female gamete (in the ovule) to form a zygote. This occurs inside the ovary of the flower after pollination.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pollen transfer (A) is pollination. Seed development (C) occurs after fertilisation. Seed dispersal (D) occurs after the fruit is formed. Fertilisation (B) is specifically the fusion of gametes.

questions.question_text: After fertilisation, the ovule develops into a:
questions.explanation_correct: After fertilisation, the ovule develops into a seed. The seed contains the embryo (baby plant) and stored food. The ovary, which contains the ovule, develops into a fruit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The ovary (not ovule) becomes the fruit (A). A flower is before fertilisation (B). Leaves are vegetative parts (D). The ovule specifically develops into a seed (C).

questions.question_text: After fertilisation, the ovary of the flower develops into a:
questions.explanation_correct: After fertilisation, the ovary swells and develops into a fruit. The fruit encloses and protects the seeds (which develop from ovules). For example, the ovary of a mango flower becomes the mango fruit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The ovule (inside the ovary) becomes the seed (A). Pollen (C) is already present before fertilisation. A new flower (D) does not form from the ovary. The ovary becomes a fruit (B).

questions.question_text: A gardener takes a stem cutting of a rose plant and plants it in moist soil. A new plant grows from it. This is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Growing a new plant from a stem cutting is vegetative propagation, a type of asexual reproduction. Only one parent plant is involved and no seeds or gametes are needed. Rose, sugarcane, and grapes can be propagated this way.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sexual reproduction (A) requires gamete fusion. Spore formation (B) involves tiny spores. Cross-pollination (D) is pollen transfer between plants. Stem cutting propagation is vegetative propagation (C).

questions.question_text: Flowers pollinated by insects are usually:

options.text: Large, brightly coloured, and fragrant with nectar
Very small with lots of pollen

questions.explanation_correct: Insect-pollinated flowers are typically large, brightly coloured, fragrant, and produce nectar to attract insects. When insects visit for nectar, pollen sticks to their body and is transferred to other flowers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Small, dull flowers (A) are typically wind-pollinated. Flowers without petals (C) are incomplete. Lots of light pollen (D) is a wind pollination feature. Insect-pollinated flowers are attractive (B) with colour, scent, and nectar.

questions.question_text: Seeds of dandelion are dispersed by wind because they have:

options.text: Hooks that attach to animal fur
Light, feathery structures that help them float in air
A hard outer shell for floating on water

questions.explanation_correct: Dandelion seeds have light, feathery or parachute-like structures (pappus) that allow them to be carried by the wind over long distances. This is an adaptation for wind dispersal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hooks (A) are for animal dispersal (e.g., Xanthium). Hard shells for floating (C) are for water dispersal. Bright colours (D) attract birds for animal dispersal. Dandelion seeds have feathery structures (B) for wind dispersal.

questions.question_text: Seeds of Xanthium (spiny cocklebur) are dispersed by animals because they have:

options.text: Hooks and spines that cling to animal fur or clothes
Light weight for floating on water

questions.explanation_correct: Xanthium seeds have hooks and spines on their surface that cling to the fur of animals or clothes of people. As the animals or people move, the seeds are carried to new locations and dispersed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wings (A) are for wind dispersal. Sweet flesh (C) attracts animals to eat fruits. Light weight (D) aids wind or water dispersal. Hooks and spines (B) allow seeds to attach to animals for dispersal.

questions.question_text:
Match the flower part with its function:
(i) Sepals - (a) Attract pollinators
(ii) Petals - (b) Produce pollen
(iii) Stamen - (c) Protect flower bud
(iv) Pistil - (d) Contains ovules
questions.explanation_correct: Sepals protect the flower bud (c). Petals attract pollinators with colour and scent (a). Stamens produce pollen grains (b). The pistil contains ovules with female gametes (d). Option A is correct.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Only option A correctly matches all four parts: Sepals-protect, Petals-attract, Stamens-produce pollen, Pistil-contains ovules.

questions.question_text: Cross-pollination is important for plants because it:

options.text: Introduces genetic variation, making plants more adaptable
Does not require any external agents

questions.explanation_correct: Cross-pollination is important because it brings pollen from a different plant, introducing genetic variation in the offspring. This makes the species more adaptable and better able to survive changing conditions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cross-pollination is not necessarily faster (A). It does require agents like wind or insects (C). It does not produce smaller seeds (D). Its key benefit is introducing genetic variation (B).

questions.question_text: Which of the following shows the correct pair of plant and its method of vegetative propagation?
questions.explanation_correct: Potato reproduces from eyes (buds on the stem tuber) and Dahlia reproduces from tuberous roots. These are correct examples of vegetative propagation from stem and root respectively.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rose propagates from stem cuttings, not leaves (A). Ginger is a stem (rhizome), not root (C). Sugarcane propagates from stem, not root (D). B correctly matches potato (stem) and dahlia (root).

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Plants produced by asexual reproduction are genetically identical to the parent.
Reason: No fusion of gametes occurs in asexual reproduction.

options.text: Both are true and the reason correctly explains the assertion
Both are true but reason does not explain assertion
Assertion is true but reason is false

questions.explanation_correct: Both are true and connected. Since asexual reproduction involves only one parent and no mixing of genetic material through gamete fusion, the offspring are genetically identical (clones) to the parent plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The offspring are indeed genetically identical, and this is directly because no gamete fusion (which would introduce variation) occurs. Both statements are true and the reason explains the assertion (A).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of events in sexual reproduction in flowering plants?

options.text: Fertilisation -> Pollination -> Seed formation -> Seed dispersal
Pollination -> Fertilisation -> Seed formation -> Seed dispersal
Seed formation -> Pollination -> Fertilisation -> Seed dispersal
Pollination -> Seed dispersal -> Fertilisation -> Seed formation

questions.explanation_correct: The correct sequence is: Pollination (pollen transfer to stigma) -> Fertilisation (fusion of gametes) -> Seed formation (ovule develops into seed) -> Seed dispersal (seeds spread to new locations).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pollination must occur before fertilisation. Seeds form after fertilisation. Dispersal is the last step. Only B shows the correct chronological order.

questions.question_text: Which part of the potato plant is used for vegetative propagation?
questions.explanation_correct: Potatoes propagate vegetatively through the eyes (buds) on the tuber. A potato tuber is actually a modified underground stem. Each eye can sprout and grow into a new plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Potato does not propagate from leaves (A), roots (B), or flowers (D). The eyes or buds on the potato tuber (C), which is a modified stem, grow into new plants.

questions.question_text: Wind-pollinated flowers usually produce large amounts of pollen because:

options.text: Most pollen is wasted as wind carries it randomly
They have more stamens than other flowers

questions.explanation_correct: Wind-pollinated flowers produce large amounts of light, smooth pollen because wind carries pollen randomly in all directions. Most pollen does not reach a stigma, so producing large quantities increases the chance of successful pollination.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pollen is not food for the plant (A). Wind-pollinated pollen is actually lighter (C), not heavier. It is not about having more stamens (D). The large production compensates for random wind dispersal (B).

questions.question_text: Which of the following seeds is dispersed by water?
questions.explanation_correct: Coconut seeds are dispersed by water. The coconut has a fibrous outer husk that makes it light and helps it float on water. This allows it to travel long distances across oceans to reach new shores.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Madar with silky hairs (A) is dispersed by wind. Xanthium with hooks (C) is dispersed by animals. Balsam (D) disperses by explosion. Coconut with its fibrous husk (B) floats on water.

questions.question_text: The three parts of the pistil are:
questions.explanation_correct: The pistil (female reproductive part) has three parts: the stigma (sticky top that receives pollen), the style (a tube connecting stigma to ovary), and the ovary (base that contains ovules with female gametes).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Anther and filament (A) are parts of the stamen (male part). Sepal, petal, stamen (C) are different flower parts. Root, stem, leaf (D) are plant organs. The pistil's parts are stigma, style, and ovary (B).

questions.question_text: An advantage of asexual reproduction in plants is that:

options.text: It is faster and requires only one parent

questions.explanation_correct: Asexual reproduction is faster than sexual reproduction and requires only one parent. There is no need for pollination, fertilisation, or seed formation, making it quicker for plants to reproduce and colonise areas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Asexual reproduction produces genetically identical (not diverse) offspring (A). It needs only one parent (B). It does not require seeds (D). Speed and single-parent requirement (C) are its advantages.

questions.question_text: In cross-pollination, pollen is transferred from one flower to another on a different plant. Which agent is responsible for pollination in grass?
questions.explanation_correct: Grass flowers are pollinated by wind. They are small, dull-coloured, and without fragrance or nectar. They produce large quantities of light, smooth pollen that is easily carried by the wind.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Grass flowers are not colourful or fragrant, so they do not attract insects (A) or animals (D). They are not aquatic (B). Wind (C) is the primary pollinating agent for grasses.

questions.question_text: In asexual reproduction, offspring are genetically different from the parent.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. In asexual reproduction, offspring are genetically identical to the parent because there is no mixing of genetic material from two parents. Only one parent is involved.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Offspring of asexual reproduction are clones of the parent. Genetic variation only comes from sexual reproduction where genetic material from two parents combines.

questions.question_text: The anther is part of the pistil and produces ovules.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. The anther is part of the stamen (male part), not the pistil (female part). The anther produces pollen grains, not ovules. Ovules are found in the ovary of the pistil.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The anther is part of the stamen (male reproductive organ) and produces pollen grains. The pistil (female organ) contains ovules in its ovary.

questions.question_text: Self-pollination can occur in bisexual flowers without the help of any external agent.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. In bisexual flowers (which have both stamens and pistil), pollen from the anther can fall directly onto the stigma of the same flower without needing wind, insects, or any other external agent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. Since bisexual flowers have both male and female parts, pollen can transfer from anther to stigma within the same flower, making self-pollination possible without external agents.

questions.question_text: After fertilisation, the petals and stamens of a flower usually fall off while the ovary develops into a fruit.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. After fertilisation, the petals, stamens, and sometimes sepals wither and fall off. The ovary enlarges and develops into a fruit, while the ovules inside develop into seeds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: After fertilisation, the flower parts that are no longer needed (petals, stamens) do fall off. The remaining ovary develops into a fruit containing seeds. This is a standard process in flowering plants.

questions.question_text: Spores are large, visible structures that can be seen easily without a microscope.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Spores are microscopic (very tiny) structures that cannot be seen with the naked eye. They are enclosed in a hard protective covering and are very light, allowing them to be carried by wind or water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Spores are extremely small and can only be seen under a microscope. Their tiny size and light weight allow them to be easily carried by wind to new locations for germination.

questions.question_text: Seed dispersal helps prevent overcrowding of plants in one area.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Seed dispersal spreads seeds away from the parent plant and from each other. This prevents overcrowding, reduces competition for water, nutrients, and sunlight, and helps plants colonise new areas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Seed dispersal is indeed important for preventing overcrowding. If all seeds fell near the parent, they would compete intensely for light, water, and nutrients, resulting in poor growth.

questions.question_text: The male reproductive part of a flower consisting of anther and filament is called the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The stamen is the male reproductive organ of a flower. It consists of the anther (which produces and releases pollen grains) and the filament (a thin stalk that supports the anther).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'stamen'. It is the male part made up of the anther (pollen-producing) and the filament (supporting stalk).

questions.question_text: The transfer of pollen grains from the anther to the stigma of a flower is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Pollination is the transfer of pollen grains from the anther (male part) to the stigma (female part). It can be self-pollination or cross-pollination, and is essential for sexual reproduction in flowering plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'pollination'. It is a crucial step before fertilisation can occur, as pollen must reach the stigma for the male gamete to travel to the ovule.

questions.question_text: After fertilisation, the ovary of a flower develops into a ___ while the ovules become seeds.
questions.explanation_correct: The ovary develops into a fruit after fertilisation. The fruit encloses and protects the seeds. For example, the ovary of a mango flower becomes the mango fruit, and the ovules inside become the mango seed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'fruit'. The transformation of the ovary into fruit and ovules into seeds is a key outcome of successful sexual reproduction in flowering plants.

questions.question_text: The breaking of an organism's body into two or more pieces, each of which grows into a new individual, is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Fragmentation is a type of asexual reproduction where the body of an organism breaks into two or more fragments, and each fragment develops into a complete new organism. Spirogyra is a well-known example.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'fragmentation'. It is different from budding (where a bud forms) or fission (where the organism divides in two). In fragmentation, multiple pieces can each regenerate.

questions.question_text: The fusion of male and female gametes during sexual reproduction is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Fertilisation is the process of fusion of male and female gametes to form a zygote. In plants, this occurs when the male gamete from the pollen grain fuses with the female gamete in the ovule.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'fertilisation'. It is the defining event of sexual reproduction, resulting in the formation of a zygote that develops into the embryo within the seed.

questions.question_text: The sticky top part of the pistil that receives pollen grains is called the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The stigma is the topmost part of the pistil. It has a sticky surface that helps pollen grains to adhere to it when they land during pollination. From the stigma, the pollen tube grows down through the style to the ovary.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'stigma'. It is the receptive surface for pollen at the top of the pistil, connected to the ovary via the style.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an advantage of spore formation as a method of reproduction?

options.text: Spores are very large and easy to find
Spores have a tough coating and can survive harsh conditions until favourable conditions arrive
Spores can only grow in warm climates

questions.explanation_correct: Spores have a hard, protective outer coating that allows them to survive harsh conditions (heat, drought, etc.) for long periods. They germinate only when favourable conditions like moisture and warmth are available.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Spores are tiny, not large (A). While some spores need moisture, the main advantage is their tough coating (B). They are not limited to warm climates (D).

questions.question_text: Seeds of balsam plant are dispersed when the ripe fruit:

options.text: Falls into water and floats away
Bursts open suddenly, scattering seeds away

questions.explanation_correct: Balsam seeds are dispersed by explosive mechanism. When the fruit ripens, it builds up pressure and suddenly bursts open, throwing the seeds away from the parent plant with force.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Balsam does not rely on birds (A), water (B), or wind (D) for seed dispersal. Its fruit bursts open explosively (C), scattering seeds to nearby locations.

questions.question_text: A flower in which sepals, petals, stamens, and pistil are all present is called a:
questions.explanation_correct: A complete flower has all four whorls: sepals, petals, stamens, and pistil. Examples include mustard, lily, and rose. An incomplete flower is missing one or more of these four parts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An incomplete flower (B) is missing at least one whorl. A unisexual flower (C) has either stamens or pistil, not both. A sterile flower (D) cannot reproduce. A flower with all four parts is complete (A).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of wind-pollinated flowers?

options.text: Bright, colourful petals and sweet fragrance

questions.explanation_correct: Bright, colourful petals and sweet fragrance are characteristics of insect-pollinated flowers, not wind-pollinated ones. Wind-pollinated flowers are usually small, dull, and without scent because they do not need to attract insects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Light pollen (A), feathery stigma (C), and large pollen production (D) are all features of wind-pollinated flowers. Bright petals and fragrance (B) are insect-pollination features.

questions.question_text: A farmer wants to grow many rose plants quickly that are identical to an existing rose plant. Which method should the farmer use?

options.text: Use stem cuttings from the existing plant

questions.explanation_correct: Stem cuttings (vegetative propagation) is the best method because it is faster than growing from seeds and produces plants genetically identical to the parent. This ensures the new plants have the same desirable features.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Seeds (A, C) take longer and may not produce identical plants. Cross-pollination (D) would introduce variation. Stem cuttings (B) are fast and produce identical clones of the parent plant.

questions.question_text: The spreading of seeds to different places away from the parent plant is called seed ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Seed dispersal is the process by which seeds are spread away from the parent plant to new locations. It occurs by various agents including wind, water, animals, and explosive mechanisms of fruits.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'dispersal'. Seed dispersal is essential to prevent overcrowding, reduce competition, and help plants colonise new areas for the survival of the species.
